biogHist.abstract: Ingada Village was established in Carnarvon around 1975 by the Churches of Christ Federal Aborigines Mission Board Inc. It was previously known as Carnarvon Mission. Ingada Village provided accommodation and access to education and training for Aboriginal children and young people. Children included both wards of the State and ones who were admitted privately. Children lived in 'scatter cottages' on the old mission site and in the Carnarvon township. After 1984 no more children were admitted to Ingada but a few children remained until 1986.
biogHist.p: Carnarvon Mission's name was changed to Ingada Village around 1975. In 1979, there were 84 children living at Ingada, but by 1983 the number of children fell to 32.

During the 1970s Carnarvon Mission and, later, Ingada Village established four 'scatter cottages' in the township and replaced Mission buildings with cottage homes for children on the old mission site. One of the cottages was called Carinya Scatter Cottage.

From 1984 there were no more children admitted to Ingada Village. However, a few children from Onslow remained at Ingada until 1986, when they were able to return to Onslow to continue their education.
The old mission site continued to offer accommodation and support for the elderly, with purpose-built facilities. On 28 January 2013, a fire destroyed many of the remaining mission-era buildings.

chronItem.event: Location - Ingada Village was located in Carnarvon

descriptiveNote.p: The Carnarvon Teens Hostel accommodated young people from Ingada Village who were going to high school or working in the Carnarvon township.

archref.repository: Global Mission Partners, Churches of Christ Federal Aborigines Mission Board Photographs
archref.abstract: Oval and playground, Carnarvon Mission' is a digital copy of an image held by Global Mission Partners in the Churches of Christ Federal Aborigines Mission Board Photographs collection. As described by historian Deslee Moyle, the image dates from the early 1980s

archref.repository: Global Mission Partners, Churches of Christ Federal Aborigines Mission Board Photographs
archref.abstract: 'Carinya scatter cottage' is a digital copy of an image held by Global Mission Partners in the Churches of Christ Federal Aborigines Mission Board Photographs collection. As described by historian Deslee Moyle, the image dates from 1980 or 1981 and shows one of the 'scatter cottages' in the Carnarvon township that were part of Ingada Village (which was the new name given to the Carnarvon Mission in 1975).

'Carnarvon Mission Ingada Village' is a history of the Churches of Christ's management of Carnarvon Mission and the Mission's later name, Ingada Village. It also includes information about the Carnarvon Teens Hostel and was written by Deslee Moyle, who has preserved many archival records relating to the Churches of Christ Federal Aborigines Mission Board (CCFAMB) and the organisation that followed it, the Australian Churches of Christ Indigenous Ministries (ACCIM). The item gives insight into life at the Mission and the Hostel.
